description:
üëâ This guide is part of the TypeScript Introduction Guides. Please follow the order:

  • Fundamentals & Data types
  • Conditionals
  • Loops & Iterators
  • Functions

Javascript is the only programming language that all the browsers understand, therefore it is a building block of web development. With it you will be able to add ‚Äúbehavior‚Äù to your websites and applications, such as interaction, data collection, programmatic interface changes based on the user's behavior and (this is very important) create HTTP requests which allow you to create asynchronous applications! üòç ¬†Don't worry if you don't understand some of these terms. That is precisely what this and the Javascript Introduction Guides are for.

A lot of the time Javascript is used in conjunction with HTML and CSS, but it actually does not need any of them. Javascript can function on its own. The browsers add something called Web APIs, which (in short) allows you to use Javascript to manipulate HTML and CSS, but in order to get there it's a good idea to understand what ‚Äúpure‚Äù Javascript can do.

To do that, you can use GitHub Pages

TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that compiles into JavaScript. TypeScript can not run on the browser like JavaScript and that is why it needs to be compiled into JavaScript before the browser can read it

Once you are comfortable with all the concepts listed in this and the other introduction Guides, a world of concepts and exciting possibilities will open-up before you!

Hello everyone and happy new year! I hope you are happy to start this hard core coding module in this darkest time of the year with a style.

This first guide on a new year is all about getting to know Next.js. We used to have Express as the first thing to learn in the back end but recently express has been loosing popularity and nobody is using it in the workinglife in Iceland while almost everyone is using Next.js. With the new App router that they introduced last year it has become one of the most sophisticated frameworks for React. io.vefskoli.is is also made with that framework. Although, when we go to Las Palmas, be prepared that the Danish and the Spanish students will probably want to use Express since they know that much better...

Their official guide is very good and touches on everything that is so important in web development except for REST API but we will do a guide on that later in this module. It even has a "Learn React Foundations" precourse in case you would like to recap a bit what we were doing last year.

description:
As you have probably seen by now React State can be pretty cool and powerful. Whenever you change the value of your state (with the setState function) it immediately shows the new value in the UI. The react hook useState works well for this when your changes are the same component.

But what happens if I want the changes to happen in a different component?

Well then you can pass the state down as props or you can lift the state to a higher component. This way you should be able to create a relatively small web without any problems.

But what happens if I want to update something in component 3 when I click something in component 4? (see picture below)

When the component tree starts to get big it can be pretty messy to try to pass the state all the way through the tree as props. That is why React has introduced the React Context. That is a way of storing state globally. In this guide we will test it out and try to figure out how to use it and what it does for us.

For showing your state management skills It is recommended that you use either React Context or some state management library such as Recoil or Redux

title: Getting started - Concepts
description:
üëâ If you haven't done so yet, go to the Tooling Guide and get yourself a Glitch account, which you can use to exercise the topics in this Guide.

Websites (and many other kinds of applications) are made up of HTML, CSS and Javascript. These are languages allow us to tell the browser what to show, how it will look like and how each part should behave.

HTML defines what should be shown on the screen and in which hierarchy, like a paragraph, a list containing a dozen items, an image, etc.

CSS defines how things look like. For example, if the color of a text should be purple or if an element should be always in the top right corner.

Javascript defines how things should behave. For example, if a message should appear when I click a button, or if more images should be loaded as the user approaches the end of an image list.

These three technologies alone compose the basis of almost all of the work we will go through in this course, and therefore should be well studied, understood and mastered.

By far, Javascript is the most complex and powerful of the three, so we will be spending more time learning it.

Many other powerful tools you will study and use were created with these three technologies, which expose how simplicity can give way to a complex and vibrant ecosystem as the web development community.

That this project doesn't need to be visually amazing it can be as simple as shapes floating around on click or on hover, the point of this guide is to teach you how to create animations in figma which you can later implement in future projects, so do not be afraid to play around and try different things, watch tutorials and read articles.

Tip: You can download a plugin called "Iconify" in figma if you want to have an easy access and quick to icons in this assignment.

  • A Button that when you press it opens up a "drawer" that slides from the side of the page, and when you click on the background the "drawer" slides back in. (The drawer does not need to have any content.)

  • A Toggle button that you can switch on and off, which can also change colors or shapes.
  • Last but not least try to create a transition between two pages on a click of a button.

description:
When creating a prototype of our project in figma the visuals are very important, because we want our prototype to be as close to final product as we possibly can. We can make it even better when we add some movement to our prototype for example:

  • Logo movements.
  • Movement when the page is loaded.
  • Loading screens.
  • Animations on click of a button.

And many more, the possibilities are endless!

With that we get to SEE and FEEL how our project behaves according to what the project looks like, another example: If our project has a very "heavy", "Metallic" and "dark" design, the animations should also FEEL "heavy", "hard" and "sharp". If our project is designed more "lightweight", the animations should feel "light" and "fluffy" and so on and so forward. It all depends on what you SEE to then apply how it should FEEL for our users. Not only does this mindset makes our project feel more premium it also makes us look more professional. Remember that attention even to smallest details is very important and makes a huge difference.

title: Design UI - Accessibility in Figma
description:
Design world has evolved since early days and people try to make websites as accessible as they can, and so it is important for us to understand how we can make the same and make world a better place for everyone. An inaccessible design, regardless of its clean appeal, fails in its main function: to communicate and translate to all users. Using Figma, our goal is to creating something more than just visually appealing designs. We are committed to creating designs that are **accessible**, ensuring that every user, regardless of their abilities, can navigate and interact effectively. In this guide we're going to learn about tool/plugins in Figma which can aid us in making our design accessible.

Here is the most popular tool used for accessibility, we will go through it's features:
    
**Stark**
        
This tool is well rounded and has everything we need to make designs accessible that why we will explore it's functionality in this guide, there are other tools which you can explore but Stark has everything we need.

---
        
**Testing Tools Explained:**

Contrast
        
- Checks the contrast ratio between two layers and evaluates it against the WCAG standards, the score is AA and AAA and our goal with that is to get as close as we can to the AAA. It Provides quick feedback on whether a background and color on a element pair is accessible, making it easier to adjust designs in real time.

Typography
        
- Checks if the font is above 11px and the alignment of the text, that way we can be sure that our font is good enough for everyone to read.

Touch Targets
        
- Similar to color contrast this gives us score AA and AAA, again we try to be as close to AAA as we can, but what is touch target? Well the name says itself and since today we can and should be able to access all web pages with our phones elemants should be big enough on our phone for us to be able to click/ touch them andd that's what "Touch Target" checks if the element is big enough for everyone.


Vision Simulator      

- There are many disabilities that affect vision wether it is color blindess, blurred vision or loss of contrast. This tool helps us to see the way that poeple with these disabilities see so that we can adjust colors, size and contrast on our website accordingly.

---

**Annotation tools Explained:**

What are Annotation tools? These are tools not for testing but marking how elements and components should be implemented in development for example:

Alt-Text

- By now you probably know what alt-tag in HTML is? Usually used on images and it is a text that is displayed if the image is not loaded currectly that's one use case another use case is when a person needs to relay on screen reader the screen reader can use alt-tag to tell our user what the image of, without it the screen reader would probably say that it is just an image but that's not explainatory for a user that has problemst with vision. With this tool we can mark what alt-tag should say, which developers later use when coding the page.

Focus Orderer
        
- This one helps designers define and visualize focus order, what is that? Imagine some with mobility disability that person is most likley realy on keyboard to navigate the website but we are the ones that need to design in what order that person goes through our page so developers can later implement it in the same order on live website. Simply put we ensure that keyboard navigation in web designs and applications is intuitive and logical.

Headings & Landmarks

- Heading works similarly to alt-text but instead of marking alt-text to images we mark headlines to headings so the developers know what kind of heading it is... H1, H2, H3 etc. Then we have Landmarks which mark sections on the pages like header, footer, main, nav and so on... These are usually also use for screen readers e.g. if you wouldd use a div insead of nav when creating navbar the screen reader would call it "a group of something.." but if we use currect tag in this case a nav tag it will address it as a navigation.

description:
Design thinking facilitator is a very important role in a team which starts a new project, not only are they responsible that everything goes according to plan so that developers can start to code at the end of the sprint, but they are also there to motivate and help the team by going through the design thinking sprint with them, invoke new ideas and insights about they're users as well as uncover irrelevant ones. In this guide your are going to be a facilitator that needs to plan out 5 day design thinking sprint based on e.g. double-diamond or SPRINT book by Jake Knapp where you need to decide which tools and exercises to use at what time and how much time you have to spent on each exercise. It can be created in a form of a template that you and your team will later use and fill out during the Las Palmas design sprint.
Keep in mind that Design Sprint is a very flexible technique - you can experiment with all kinds of tool, you can use different methods, you can use it however it may help you.

description:
This guide is a bit special in the way that when you review this guide you will do the review in person (in the classroom or through a video call on Slack)

The modern browsers offer loads of Web APIs (Application Programming Interfaces) for the developers to use, but some are more commonly used than others.

This guide is all about exploring the endless possibilities that JavaScript (and hence also TypeScript) has to offer. JavaScript has a few built in APIs that you can use and that you have already used like the DOM API and the forms API. Here is a complete overview of all built-in APIs that JavaScript has to offer.

You can use this guide to dive deeper into web development (in a practical way) or have a bit fun with TypeScript.

üíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíª The practical: üíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíªüíª

The most commonly used APIs by web developers are these:

  • DOM - working with HTML elements in the TypeScript
  • Forms - checking validity of inputs and helping users fill out the correct information
  • Fetch - Getting data from external resources (this is what Module 4 is all about)
  • Storage - saving data in the browser so that it stays there even if a user refreshes the page
  • History - going back or forward (like using the back and forward buttons of the browser)

Use the DOM and Form APIs if you want to get a deeper understanding of what we have already been doing in this module.

Use the Fetch API if you want to prepare for what is coming in the next module.

Use the Storage or History APIs if you want to see what is available.

üïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏è The Fun: üïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏èüïπÔ∏è

If you want to have a bit of fun (that is often the best way to learn something) here are a few APIs that could be nice to play around with:

  • Canvas - A nice and fun way of creating graphics with JavaScript, you can make games, animations or anything you can think of
  • Web Audio - A fun API to play sounds on a website, you can for example create a digital piano or other instruments
  • Media Capture and Media Stream - Here you can get the video from the users camera and play with that

You can even go a bit out of your comfort zone and use third party libraries (even though that will be strictly forbidden in the final project for this module). Doing that will practice the important skill of reading documentation but you will be doing a lot of that as a web developer. Such 3rd party libraries are for example:

  • Phaser.io - a game engine to create computer games in JavaScript
  • p5 - a library to create fun animations
  • Greensock - a library to create micro-animations for websites
  • aframe.io - a library to create VR with JavaScript

description:
This guide is called the Design Introduction, and now that we know a thing or two about Figma we can move on to more theoretical stuff. In this Guide we are going to learn about strategy, structure, and making a statement, and understanding what looks good and why it works, a unique blend of functionality and visual appeal. Here are a couple of strategy's to always keep in mind when working on design:

  • Elements of Design: These are the foundational blocks every designer starts with. From the lines that guide the eye, to the colors that evoke a certain mood, they're the basic ingredients in every design recipe.
  • Principles of Design: Think of these as the guidelines. They help structure the way we use our elements, ensuring our designs aren‚Äôt just eye-catching, but also clear and cohesive.
  • Typography: Beyond just picking fonts, typography is about conveying information in the most visually effective way.
  • Color Theory: Colors can speak volumes. knowing how they can be combined can help us create a visual impact of emotion, culture, and hierarchy on our page.

Design is a wide topic and we are just beginning to scratch the surface, but the really good thing to do is to go on websites like awwwards.com and take 5 min everyday looking at the designs and train our eyes to get used to layouts and structures, that way we get better everyday.

description:
Now that you have Lo-Fi Wireframe and your style guide you are ready to create Hi-Fi Prototype, which is as close as possible to a true representation of your projects final look. Since we get all of our layout from wireframe and all of our components from our style guide we can easily combine these two and create a polished nice looking prototype which will also behave as our real project, we can do that by creating animations and cool effects, that way it feels even more like fully functioning product. We can create nice animations with smart animate and other prototype features in figma.

Of course even if we have all of the layout from wireframe we can make adjustments and try out other things if we feel that something can be better, but the key is to pay attention to small details because these small details make a huge difference when showcasing your prototype it not only gives us a nice looking prototype but also this nice feeling and magic that we want to create when using our prototype.

title: Back-end - Workshop (16h-20h)
topicsList:
• Internet Protocols
    • HTTPS - The protocol that transfers our HTML (basically all the content of the page) from the server to the client
    • TCP/IP - Kind of like the post service of the internet. It takes care of where data should go and how to make sure it got there, other similar protocols are UDP
    • SSH - is a way to connect to the terminal of a remote computer (for example web server). This is very common and a good reason to learn your terminal commands pretty well because you won't have any graphical interface there. Other similar protocols are Telnet and FTP
    • Others - There are loads of other protocols that you might be interested in, for example e-mailing protocols, routing protocols and more
  • Programming languages
    • PHP - Is a programming language made for back-end and was dominating as such in the 90's. Today it's legacy is mostly CMS systems like WordPress and Drupal although it has got some uprising in recent years with the fast PHP7 (now PHP8) and frameworks like Laravel
    • Python - Is a general purpose programming languages that got very popular as a back end language in the early 2000's with frameworks like Django, Bottle and Flask
    • .NET - Is probably the most used back-end framework today (at least in Iceland). It is used by all the banks and other large, conservative institutions. This Microsoft specific framework for C# is also used in a pretty popular CMS system called Umbraco used by some web agencies in Iceland
    • Other - There are plenty of other programming languages to explore. There are funny once like Brainfuck and Whitespace and then there are low level once like C and Rust and there is even an Icelandic one called Fj√∂lnir
  • CI/CD
    • Continuous Integration - is the automatic process that takes place when you push your code to the main branch, this includes testing and building the code (like on Netlify or Vercel).
    • Continuous delivery - Is kind of a continuation of the continuous integration where the code is automatically ready to be published. This is very important in large projects that tend to hang because the group is never ready to publish anything because there is always something missing
    • DevOps - CI/CD is a part of DevOps but DevOps just takes to the entire process, not just development but also running the servers and more general IT subjects
    • Kupernetes - Is a way to help practice all of this by combining and "orchestrating" (meaning just to manage them) Docker containers. It is widely considered a best practice for large projects that have many developers from different backgrounds contributing to the project
  • Testing
    • End-to-end testing - Are tests that run the entire process of building the app and running it in the browser. This could for example be an automated test ensuring that only logged in users can see a page or that screen readers can always read some section of the page etc‚Ä¶
    • Unit testing - Are tests that test the output of a certain function in your code. For example if you have made a function that should return HTML code for a card when you call it with the text that should be in the card. This would make sure that all the elements that should be in the card are there
    • A/B testing - is when you publish a different version of your page to part of the users. For example if you want to see how people would react to the background being ping you could select to publish the page with pink background color to 10% of your users and see how if they engage with the page as long as others or if they are more likely to buy some certain product on your page than others etc‚Ä¶

If you would like to pick some other topic you can also bring it up with a teacher and ask if that is ok.

The structure of this process should be as follows:

  • Presentation - The work will be presented at a Seminar. Details to be announced on Slack.

description:
Introduction to Figma

Figma has rapidly become one of the foremost tools for web design and development. Embraced by numerous web agencies both in Iceland and globally, its appeal lies not just in its capabilities for web design, but also in graphics creation, prototyping, presentation, and collaboration. This guide will introduce you to the fundamental tools within Figma and showcase what they offer.

Setting Up Figma

  1. We start by going to Figma.com and creating our account.
  2. Now in the upper right corner we can click on "+Design file" and create our first project.
  3. We're here! Feel free to roam around and explore and get familiar with tools of Figma.

We can use figma in two ways in the browser like we're doing now or we can download and install a figma desktop application here are a couple of pros and cons for both.

Figma desktop:

pros:

  • Performance: While Figma is optimized for browsers, the desktop app can sometimes offer slightly better performance, especially with larger files.
  • Offline Mode: The desktop app allows you to work on files without an internet connection (though real-time collaboration requires connectivity).
  • Keyboard Shortcuts: Some keyboard shortcuts, especially system-level ones, work more seamlessly in the desktop app and allows us to work faster on our projects.
  • OS Integration: Easier integration with other apps on your computer, like using third-party plugins or dragging and dropping files.
  • Dedicated Workspace: Without the distractions of other browser tabs or notifications, you can focus solely on design.

cons:

  • Updates: Even though Figma's desktop app updates automatically, there might be slight delays compared to the browser version.

Figma browser version:

pros:

  • Universal Access: As long as you have an internet connection and a modern browser, you can access Figma from any computer without needing to install any software.
  • Always Updated: The browser version will always be the most up-to-date since updates are pushed immediately to the web platform.
  • No Installation Required: No need to download or install anything, which can be handy on shared or restricted computers.

cons:

  • Performance: While Figma is highly optimized for web, for some users, especially with extensive design files, the browser version might feel a tad slower.
  • Internet Dependency: You always need an internet connection to access and work on your files.
  • Browser Limitations: Certain functionalities or keyboard shortcuts might be restricted due to browser limitations.

In conclusion Figma for browser is for lightweight uses and Figma for desktop is for more extensive projects, but for our studies it's recommend to download the desktop version.

Now let's get started with Figma! Below you can see what every tool in figma does.

themeIdea.title: Brief
themeIdea.description:
Project Brief: "EcoBytes" - A Mini Blog on Sustainable Tech

Overview:

EcoBytes is a mini blog platform dedicated to exploring the intersection of technology and sustainability. Its mission is to educate and inspire tech enthusiasts and environmental advocates by highlighting innovative tech solutions that contribute to a sustainable future. The platform will feature articles on sustainable tech trends, green computing, and eco-friendly gadgets.

Objective:

Build a simplistic yet impactful blog using Next.js for the frontend and any of the above mentioned as the headless CMS. This project aims to provide students with practical experience in developing a content-driven website, focusing on content management, website performance, and user engagement.

Key Features:

  1. Homepage: A clean and engaging landing page that displays featured articles, with an emphasis on high-quality images and concise summaries.
  2. Articles Page: A list of all articles sorted by publication date. Each article entry should include a thumbnail, title, summary, and a "Read More" link.
  3. Article Details: Individual pages for each article, showcasing the full content, including text, images, and embedded videos or social media posts.
  4. About Page: A brief page about EcoBytes, its mission, and the importance of sustainable technology.

Technical Requirements:

  • Use Next.js to create a responsive and SEO-friendly blog site.
  • Implement Prismic for content management, designing custom types for articles that include fields for titles, summaries, body content, and images.
  • Ensure the site is accessible and performs well on both desktop and mobile devices.
  • Utilize Next.js's static generation features for fast loading times and improved SEO.

Learning Objectives:

  • Practice integrating a headless CMS (Prismic) with a React-based framework (Next.js) for dynamic web development.
  • Develop skills in creating SEO-friendly web pages with Next.js.
  • Learn to manage and structure content effectively using Prismic.
  • Enhance understanding of responsive design and web performance optimization.

Deliverables:

  • A deployable mini blog site with at least 3 sample articles showcasing different sustainable technologies. (you can use chatGPT to generate text fro the articles)
  • Documentation (in the README.md file) outlining the project structure, development process, and instructions for adding new articles via Prismic.

Timeline:

The project is structured to be completed within three days:

  • Day 1: Setup and initial development. Create the Next.js project, design the website layout, and integrate Prismic.
  • Day 2: Content creation and styling. Define the custom types in Prismic, add sample content, and apply styles to the website.
  • Day 3: Testing, optimization, and presentation preparation. Ensure the site is responsive, performant, and ready for deployment.

description:
Understanding CMS Systems

When a web developer delivers a project to a normal person, it is not a good idea to ask them to "just change the code and commit to GitHub when you need to add some content to your page, watch out for conflicts because they are bad, good luck!".

Why We Need CMS Systems

We need some sort of a system for our customers. Those systems are often called CMS systems (Content Management System). Now that you know how to add data to databases and implement authentication, you can even make your own CMS system, and sometimes that is a good way to go to simplify things for the customer. But there are many existing CMS systems out there that take care of these things for you, and that is what we are going to explore in this module.

The Evolution of CMS Systems

There are many such systems. For a long time, WordPress used to rule the world of CMS systems, but now there are many rivals coming up with more modern technology. One of them is Prismic, and that one is widely used in the web industry in Iceland today others that are also used are Dato, Payload and Sanity . This guide is about exploring the power of CMS systems and realize their potential for our web applications.

themeIdea.title: Collaborative work effortness of unity
themeIdea.description:
Due to the nature of this project you will need to find someone to work with. It is alright if you are more than two people in a group and in fact you can have as many people in your group as you like, the whole class can work together on this if you like.

The group (two or more students) needs to do the following (do all of this together in person or through Zoom):

BRANCES and pull requests:
  • One student creates a repository with a few files and invites all the other students as collaborators to the repository
  • The students will then receive an email where they need to accept the collaboration
  • The students will then need to do the following:
    • Clone the repository to their own computer
    • Make a new branch in the recently cloned repository
    • Make sure that you are working on the new branch
    • Make some changes to the code
    • Switch to main branch
      • Observe that your changes are not there anymore
    • Switch back to your original branch and observe the changes comming back
    • Push the new code to GitHub by writing "git push origin xxxxx" where xxxxx is the name of your branch
      • Observe the new code in GitHub
    • Make a pull request (on GitHub) with your new branch DO NOT MERGE THE PULL REQUEST
  • When the other people in your group have done that as well you can do the following:
    • Check out pull requests in GitHub
    • Choose one pull request and write a comment to the pull request (code review)
    • Merge the pull request into main
    • Now you should be able to see all the changes on the main branch in your repository.
    • other students can now switch to the main branch and pull the code to get the newest changes

description:
Introduction

Now that the group project is coming up it is important to practice using tools like Git. When working together in large groups it is important to be able to test out different things in the project without being afraid of ruining the code. This is where git branches come in handy.

The recommended way to work is to:

  1. Invite collaborators to your GitHub repository
  2. Create branch for each feature you are working on
  3. Make a pull request to the main branch
  4. Someone else from your group should then review and merge the pull request, leaving comments on your code
    • This kind of comment is called a "code review"

title: Reading code
description:
Before we start to dive into TypeScript it is good to stop a bit and try to understant where we are and what we know. A good way to check yourown knowledge is to try to read through some code and see how much of it you can understand.

The art of reading code has become more and more important skill in recent years. You have already read through some code when reviewing some of your classmates assignments and that is a very good practice. Code reviews are a big part of professional programmers day and just as important as writing code because it ensures good code quality. With the intrduction of Large Language Models like ChatGPT and Claude more and more code is written by machines and that way it becomes even more important to know how to read code because we need to be able to understand what the AI is trying to do.

In this guide you will need to read through some code and try to understand it, Write comments or take notes to try to explain the code that you see and make sense of it yourself. If you have troubles understanding it, try to ask ChatGPT or Claude to explain it and see if that helps.

- Read throug the whole code
- Comment what you thin each part of the code does
- Use Google, ChatGPT or Claude to explain the code
- Write another comment and compare it to your guess to see how far you were from the truth.

If you have a hard time finding some code you can use this repository that I created with 10 levels of code. It is alright if you can not explain all of them but try to go as far as you can: 

https://github.com/ellertsmari/reading-code

When you are ready, push your code with all the comments into a new GitHub repository and return it here. And remember to make a review ;-) 

Good luck!

classes.title: Git and Github tutorial for beginners

title: Getting started - Tooling
description:
Code Editor

A code editor is the main tool in a web developer's toolbelt. In modern times it's not only the tool you'll be writing the code in but it's also the ecosystem that will be helping you go through the complex modern development environment, with it's built-in features and plugins. In this Guide you should install and get acquainted the main code editor we'll be using in the course: VSCode.

Accounts

As a web developer you will need to have online tools to help on your work. To start with, create an account on Github and Figma, and read up on them.

Github hosts code you create with Git, and we will be using it to deliver almost all work to be done throughout the course.

Terminal

The terminal is a software that allows you to run scripts and different kinds of software just by typing their names and some options in a command line. It will prove very useful in your day-to-day life as a web developer.

Git

Git is a versioning system that widely used to keep track of different code versions (so that it is clear what changed with each iteration). Github is a company that makes use of this technology to host many Git repositories. Learning Git is paramount when dealing with code both because it organizes the workflow and because it makes it very easy to collaborate and share your work.

Markdown

Markdown is a way to write rich text with only a simple editor. It is going to be used in every project in this course to create a README.md file, which should contain relevant information about that work. Markdown can also used to manage the content of ¬†websites that don't rely on the use of databases for such.

description:
HTML and CSS are two of the web's building blocks. They allow us, respectively, to define what are the contents of a website and how it should look like. In this module you will get in touch with the syntax, learn all fundamental parts of each and create a website.

If you never worked with either before, the syntax might look a little weird at first but it grows on you and you'll feel at home in no time. Focus on creating clean code, which you understand 100%. Make extensive use of sandboxes (with CodePen or W3Schools, for example). Get comfortable and use HTML's semantic tags (header, main, section, footer, nav, etc). Go through the list of HTML and CSS topics described in this Guide to make sure you haven't overlooked anything important.

It's also a good moment to learn a bit about Developer Tools, which all major browsers offer. With these tools you'll be able to inspect your work and understand what's really happening when the browser uses your files.

But none of that is much fun if you can't share, so you'll also release a website on the web using a service such as Github Pages. With this knowledge it will be possible to make all your great work publicly available for friends and potential future clients!

title: Design UI - Redesign
description:
Alright, Now that you learned about accessibility and responsivness in figma, so now let's take up a notch and use our knoweledge and skills to redesign a website by turning some "meh" designs into "WOW" masterpieces. But why redesign matters? Think of a website that's not quite cutting it. Maybe it's hard to read or doesn't work well on your phone. We're going to fix that. A redesign isn't only about making a site look better but it's also about making it work better for everyone.

By the end of this project, we'll have a website that not only looks fresh and modern but also is super user-friendly. This is our chance to take what we've learned and use it to make something better ‚Äî and learn even more in the process.

Let's dive in and see how we can turn an old website into something we're proud of.

- Present a side-by-side comparison to showcase your design and the old one.

Websites you could redesign:

1. [computer.is](https://computer.is/)
    - Why This Website Looks Bad? The homepage appears quite busy and cluttered. There's a lot happening on the screen which can overwhelm users and make it difficult to focus on the most important elements, there are different font styles and sizes which can create a disjointed visual experience. Consistent typography is key to a clean and professional look, the right side of the page is heavy with text, pricing, and promotions, which can lead to information overload. Simplifying the information presented at one time can make for a cleaner interface, responsivness could be a lot better

1. [IMDb.com](imdb.com)
    - Why This Website Looks Bad? Even though IMDb website‚Äôs homepage was revamped recently, its product page layouts for movies and TV shows have remained the same. This layout uses a very narrow boxed design. This makes the pages look cluttered and more difficult to navigate the page and to find more information. The terrible choice of the font makes it harder to read its content as well.

3. [wikipedia.com](https://www.wikipedia.com/)
    - Why This Website Looks Bad? Since Wikipedia is a non-profit website that is maintained with the help of donations, we can‚Äôt be too harsh on its design. After all, it‚Äôs providing a public service. However, we believe a better design for its article pages could prove it much more useful and user-friendly. Especially to attract younger audiences. The content formatting of the articles needs a lot of work. Wikipedia articles use a fullscreen design and as a result, the text paragraphs are stretched too long. And makes it difficult to read. Above all, the site is in need of a proper navigation system.

knowledge.knowledge: Understand Design Thinking and what it implies

title: Design UX - Design Thinking (12h-16h)
topicsList:
topics are a way you can get in touch with the main topics surrounding the subject of this Learning Guide. Use them to direct your research and get in touch with important terminology and concepts.

  1. EMPATHIZE : Work to fully understand the experience of the user for whom you are designing. Do this through observation, interaction, and immersing yourself in their experiences.
  2. DEFINE: Process and synthesize the findings to form a user point of view that you will address with your design.
  3. IDEATE: Explore a wide variety of possible solutions through generating a large quantity of diverse possible solutions, allowing you to step beyond the obvious and explore a range of ideas. creating
  4. PROTOTYPE: Transform your ideas into a physical form so that you can experience and interact with them and, in the process, learn and develop more empathy.
  5. TEST: Try out and use observations and feedback to refine prototypes, learn more about the user, and refine your original point of view.

themeIdea.title: Create a Design Thinking template for your module 4 project
themeIdea.description:

  • Problem statement
  • User Interview Script
  • User Interview notes
  • Empathy map
  • Persona/s
  • User Journey map
  • Storyboard/s and Scenarios (drawings and text on board)
  • Brainstorming exercises (notes on board - divergent/convergent)
  • User feedback on testing wireframe and/or hifi prototype.

And set it up as to witch phase each methodology was used:

  • EMPATHIZE
  • DEFINE
  • IDEATE
  • PROTOTYPE
  • TEST

description:
Design Thinking is a systematic process of thinking which empowers even the most traditional thinker to develop new, innovative solutions to the problem at hand. Everybody can be creative by following this process ‚Äì it's human-centred creativity with purpose.

Divided into four distinct phases ‚Äì

  • 1) Discover ‚Äî look in a fresh way, notice new things and gather insights.
  • 2) Define ‚Äìmake sense of all the possibilities. Which matters most? Which should we act on first? What is feasible? The goal here is to develop a clear creative brief that frames the fundamental design challenge.
  • 3) Develop ‚Äìsolutions or concepts are created, prototyped, tested and iterated. This process of trial and error helps designers to improve and refine their ideas.
  • 4) delivery - resulting project a is finalized, produced and launched.

title: React - Components
description:
If you are reading this, that means you have already been through all the blood (Data Types), sweat (conditionals and loops) and tears (functions) on your journey of learning how to code. Your weapon of choice, JavaScript is made for the web. You can instantly share your creations with the world just through one link unlike programmers of other programminglanguages. Now it is time for you to move on to a more professional usage of JavaScript, namely **React**.

React is the framework that won the [framework wars](https://medium.com/codex/the-javascript-framework-war-is-over-bd110ddab732) that stormed the web development world in the beginning of the 21st century. As the winner they also define the world we live in today and the basic building blocks of a React application is called a **component**

The component is a building block that enables you to focus on one thing at a time. From now on you can have your hamburger menu in one file, nav bar in one file, footer in one and combine them all in the frontPage file. Think about how easy it will make the groupwork in Module 4!

description:
Non relational databases (or NoSQL), like they are sometimes called, have been gaining popularity in recent years. They differ from relational databases in the way that the relations between the data is not the main concern of the developer when creating the database. This causes data to be repeated and sometimes it can be hard to connect different datasets. On the other hand changing the data schema is much easier than in relational databases and there fore NoSQL has been gaining popularity in agile software development where things can change quickly and developers need to respond quickly to the changes.

To sum it up the for NoSQL:

PROS:

  • Easy to change the schema "on the fly"
  • More availability in the cloud (database as a service)
  • Data is often stored as JSON

CONS:

  • Data relation can become complicated
  • The data might change so there is no promise that it will always look the way it does
  • Lack of support in older software (legacy systems)

description:
When we are creating a prototype for a project we start by creating the wireframe to layout everything quickly we want to have on our website, but what's the next step? You would probably think that it is time for the hi-fi prototype but there is one step in between which is called style guide. But what actually is a style guide? It is a place were we create all of the components that we want to use in our hi-fi prototype based on previously created wireframe and moodboard, colors, fonts, buttons, text fields, logos and whatever we want. Because we have everything connected we also posses more control over everything in our prototype so if there will be a need to change that one color that we used one every button in our prototype instead of doing it manually we can just go back to our style guide and if everything is connected properly we can just change color there.

You probably wonder what is the difference between style guide and design system? Well first off you would probably create a design system for much much larger projects so think of it as this huge bubble that contains Design principles, patterns and design rules that whole company uses, and inside of this bubble is another bubble where we have style guide which contains typography, icons, grid, colors etc. You can also create another bubble called Pattern library/Component library which can contain buttons, navigation and other components if you want to organize your design system better. To keep things simple in this guide we will only focus on style guide where you can also create components like buttons, navigation etc. especially if we are not making a project of that huge scope.

  • Your goal by the end of the sprint should be to have a solution to a problem you have been researching, and idea for MVP(Minimal Viable Product)
  • Don't be afraid to experiment, have fun!

description:
Designers! Did you know that you can transition from the foundational design thinking techniques you've learned in module 3 into: structured, yet agile Double Diamond Design Sprint. But what is a Design Sprint? It is a process similar to Design thinking but accelerated and condenced into 5 day process(usually), formulated for quick decision-making, and effective prototyping. Engage => Evolve => Execute. The idea of design sprint is to take all the best parts of design thinking like: User interviews, Empathy Maps, User Personas, crazy8's... everything that we think come in handy and construct a schedule for these 5 days and use these tools as efficiently as we can to solve our problem and come up with a solution(which would be a prototype in our case). Do you remember this guy ? ![image](https://raw.githubusercontent.com/JakubM1999/DoubleDiamond/refs/heads/main/Frame10.png)

We used this model in the design thinking in module 3 and we can do it here as well! Think of every phase like it's each day in the week so e.g. Context & Discovery - day 1, Define - day 2, Ideation - day 4 and Conecpt - day 5 by following this logic you can use only nessisery tool that you think you will need from design thinking and use it in your design sprint. The key is to follow a schedule and be flexible another e.g. Day 2(Define pahes) - there isn't enough time to do a journey map which you have planned on your schedule before day ends, but you have done empathy maps and user personas and you and the group is satisfied with the resaults, "We all understands what our user needs" then it's ok to skip it and start the new day with a new phase like it is in schedule rather than delay the schedule because you didn't do a journey map which you don't really need... That's why it is flexible, annd finally why do we even do it? We do it because there isn't any time limit on design thinking, we could do it for weeks but if you don't have weeks and have deadlines you also need a process that can help us achive this goal before the deadline and that's where design sprint structure comes. Hopefully now you understand what design sprint is. In this guide we will create a 5 day design sprint schedule which we will later use in module 4 group project. The group can later decide which schedule they want to use. Try to pick and chose the best tools from design thinking that you like to work with and you think are most usefull. Remember since this process is flexible and everyone does it diffrently so don't be afraid to make it your own and try different tools or techniques, go all of just like when doing a UI design:)

title: Design UI - Data visualization/Dashboard design
description:
When it comes to visualizing data in our application or website, the most important aspect is UX, which makes our charts readable and the user journey through data seamless and intuitive. A well-designed dashboard does not only present numbers but tells a story, guiding the viewer through the data to insightful conclusions and outcomes. Here are a couple of points to keep in mind which you probably alreaady know:

- Clarity: Ensure that each chart shows a clear message. Avoid overcomplicating visuals with excessive detail that can overwhelm the user.
 
- Consistency: Maintain a consistent design throughout the dashboard with similar color schemes, typography, and visual hierarchy to aid in quick understanding.

- Context: Provide context for your data. Tooltips, legends, and annotations can help users understand the full picture without having to guess what they're looking at.

- Comparability: Structure your data visualizations to enable easy comparison between different datasets, allowing users to spot trends and patterns.

- Accessibility: Design with accessibility in mind to ensure that users with disabilities can also interpret and navigate your dashboard effectively.

- Responsiveness: Your dashboard should be fully functional and visually coherent on a variety of devices and screen sizes.

There is also Interactivity which Incorporates interactive elements such as filters, sliders, and drill-downs to allow users to explore the data in depth on their terms but that dependss on the data as well.

description:
React is a great framework to create interactive web applications, but it can also be used to create other kinds of software, such as apps for smartphones and even desktop computers! React Native (and even Electron) are frameworks that will help you do just that. In this Guide you will explore one or more of these tools and learn a bit more about the possibilities of React.

There are other frameworks that do something similar and probably the most popular alternative to React Native is Dart, it is a so called "multi platform framework" and that means you write your code in one language and it will work on Android and iOS (sometimes also on the web). Alternatively people write apps for iOS in a language called SWIFT or Objective C and for Android in a language called Kotlin or Java. Dart is written in a programming language called GO and if you are feeling adventurous feel free to do this guide in Dart‚Ä¶.

themeIdea.title: Choose one of the two solutions suggested here below
themeIdea.description:
First solution:

  • Go to codewars and practice making functions that solve all different kinds of problems
    • Register to the page ( you can join a clan called Vefskólinn )
    • Start coding a problem in TypeScript marked as 8 kyu
      • If you manage to solve it you can take anotherone similar level.
      • When you start to get bored of 8kyu you can take a 7kyu challenge
      • Try to make far enough to be able to solve a 6kyu challenge
    • To make this even more competitive: For anyone reaching more honor from solving Katas than me before the Las Palmas trip I will personally pay for their dinner one of the evenings we are out there (currently I have 218 honor points just for solving Katas) 
    • Return a link to your codewars profile

Second solution:

  • Submit:

    • GitHub Pages link to the live page
    • Add comments for each relevant code block

  • Exercise description:

    • Create a contact list where every contact must have a name and email, and can (i.e. might not have) have phoneNumber and company.

    • The script must contain the following functions:

      Before, a few explanations:
      - Parameter - Read about it here https://www.w3schools.com/js/js_function_parameters.asp
      - Output - A message that  the function should output in the console. Use console.log()

      • add( contact ) - Adds a new contact to the list
        • Parameters: 
          • contact: Object containing information to create a new contact
        • Outputs
          • Error
            • “Duplicate was found” (email address is the unique identifier)
            • “Missing fields” if name or email are not present in the passed in object
          • Success
            • “ was added”
      • remove( email ) - Remove corresponding contact / Email address is the unique identifier
        • Parameters
          • email: Email address
        • Outputs
          • Error
            • “Contact not found”
          • Success
            • “ was removed”
      • edit( email, newData ) - Update/Increment the corresponding contact’s data with the information that’s passed in / Email address is the unique identifier
        • Parameters
          • email: Email address
          • newData: object representing the new information for the contact
        • Outputs
          • Error
            • “Contact not found”
          • Success
            • “ was updated”
      • get( email ) - Output information for the corresponding contact / Email address is the unique identifier
        • Parameters
          • email: Email address
        • Outputs
          • Error
            • “Contact not found”
          • Success
            • “name:
              Email:
              Phone number:
              Company: ”
      • listAll() - List all contacts available in the contact list
        • Parameters
          • None
        • Output example
          • “Anna Valsdóttir ana@tskoli.is, Jón Jónsson jon@tskoli.is, Hildur Eriksdóttir hildur@tskoli.is”
      • clear() - Remove all contacts from the list
        • Parameters
          • None
        • Output
          • “The contact list was cleared”

    • All functions must be available to use from the Console

    • Showing results via DOM manipulation is not required but is welcome and would replace the use of console.log()

description:
üëâ This guide is part of the Javascript Introduction Guides. Please follow the order:

  • Fundamentals & Data types
  • Conditionals
  • Loops & Iterators
  • Functions

Functions are an incredibly useful feature of programming languages because they allow us to encapsulate/abstract behavior. For example, if you need a certain task to be performed multiple times in your software, maybe a dog has to bark until it gets clicked, then you can create a "bark" function and have it be called/invoked every second or so.

Of course having a dog bark endlessly is probably not very useful but you will find out that functions are your friends and even start calling your coding style ‚Äúfunctional programming‚Äù at some point.

Pro tip: Do not rush through this Guide as learning functions well is key for all Javascript work.

module.title: 7 - Exploration
module.description: Since its conception, the world of web development is ever-changing and evolving. This nature means it is important to be able to explore and learn its new capabilities in order to stay up-to-date as a professional. In this project the students explore multiple trending and promising topics in order to widen their view over established web development.

description:
For this Guide the students choose a subject according to their interests to research and work on individual projects under the guidance of an instructor. The main point of this project is to experiment with future technological innovations in web development. ¬†

The outcomes of the project are defined by the students themselves and then validated by the instructor. ¬†A weekly status meeting with the instructor (3 in total) should be scheduled to discuss ideas and check on the progress of the work.

The structure of this process should be as follows:

  • Research Plan - the student creates a document that details what they would like to research and work on. This should be ready before the first status meeting (around 4 days)
  • Weekly status meetings - each meeting should be held before the end of each week. Agenda: talk about what has been done in the previous days, discuss issues and debate ideas and introduce the plan for the next week
  • Development - this is the main work, creating the product, paper or otherwise agreed on outcome
  • Feedback request - the work should be submitted for assessment using io.tskoli.dev, in order to obtain feedback from a peer. This should happen around the end of the third week, at the announced time. Note: the pass/no pass vote will be ignored.
  • Polishing - After getting a review from a peer, the student should finish off the work by polishing it and making it ready for the presentation
  • Presentation - The work will be presented at a Seminar. Details to be announced on Slack.
  • Evaluation¬† - The final grade for this project will be composed by
    • Research Plan (10%)
    • Status Meetings (10%)
    • Your Review Grade from io.tskoli.dev ¬†(15%)
    • Presentation ¬†(65%)

description: Wireframes are crucial when we are designing a website, it is a blueprint and rough sketch of our website which shows us how our website is going to look like. We can save a lot of time by creating something that is often very low fidelity (grayscale shapes) and think about layout and hierarchy of our website before we start creating any styling. Hierarchy is a very important aspect of this process since it determines what is the most important information on our website and what is least important. In this guide You will create a wireframe and have hierarchy in mind when laying out all of the components and information you want to have on your website.

title: React - State
description:
If you thought props was cool, wait until you learn about state. That is the greatest, and probably also the most debated feature of React. State is what makes react...uhh...well... react. It makes React react to users input.
![image]( data:image/webp;base64,)
There are all sorts of state management libraries that have been built to complement react from as simple library as [recoil](https://recoiljs.org/) to as complex crazyness as [redux](https://redux.js.org/) but in this module we are just going to focus on the built in features such as useState and useEffect

title: Design UI - Responsivness
description:
In today's world, it's crucial for websites to look and function well across all screen sizes and devices. The Mobile-First approach, also known as  responsive design, involves designing the mobile version of a site before scaling it up to larger devices. Imagine that we have create a desktop screen design in figma we have everything well layedout and it looks really nice, we are very happy with how it came out but now it's time to create aa mobile version of this website because it will either way be accessible on phones... Now we have a problem because now we are not sure how to fit all of this layout on such small screen and we feel like this guy... ![image](https://files.oaiusercontent.com/file-3n4zxv9qtYpqunxBEu3ctIrI?se=2024-09-25T14%3A29%3A24Z&sp=r&sv=2024-08-04&sr=b&rscc=max-age%3D604800%2C%20immutable%2C%20private&rscd=attachment%3B%20filename%3Da5ce09e0-9392-4c1e-ae01-c7f8b0142dde.webp&sig=WSITeRTCjt9dZnqlWghd9pGKUN%2BJ%2Bui0erHVEKClS0U%3D)

It's of course possible but wouldn't it be easier to just start from a small screen then go into a bit bigger like a tablet and then desktop, it sure would ;) so this is what we are going to do in this guide. We will use figma tools like autolayout and constrains to make our design scale and go from mobile through tablet to desktop.

title: SPECIALITY - UI Design - prototype handoff
description:
When we have completed our design prototype, the next step is to make sure that the developers can use and implement your design in the code. This proccess is called **design handoff**. You might wonder what  exactly happens during this process? Well, it's all about clear communication between designers and developers, the prototype you created must show your design intentions clearly, ensuring that the developers have everything they need to make the prototype into a real product.

In this guide we will focus on how to set up a design handoff process and which tools to use. You'll learn how to prepare your design for handoff and annotate you work for developers to follow smoothly

Remember, the better your handoff, the smoother your design will be implemented!

title: Design UI - Atomic Design
description:
Like programming UI design has many frameworks and methods to help us work faster and more efficiently, atomic design is one of those methodologys. What is Atomic design? It is a way for us to create reuasble components from single buttons to more complex components like cards or forms, here is how it works. Everything we see and touch in our daily lives are build out of atoms which are the smallest functional unist, then you have Molecules which are build from two or more atoms, next you have more complex structures calles organisms whicch are build out of two or more molecules.

![image](https://i.ibb.co/PWGH4Hk/EXAMPLEff.png)

This is just a simplified explanation on how our universe works but try to apply these principles to UI design, let's say that you are building a design system where do you start? Well you should start with the smallest thing like a button for example, you can already see similarity this button is our atom small and simple, now let's say that we have three atoms: a button, a label and simple input filed, let's try to combine these atoms into a molecule, what do we get? Well should get something that resambles a search bar, after that we crate an organism which is something crated out of molecules and atoms like a navbar, and this is what we created.

![image](https://i.ibb.co/tZjqjPt/EXAMPLE.png)

Using this process when designing our website becomes a bit easier and concistent, by starting small and builing upon it, this process naturally works with react when we get to coding. Like I mentioned earlier this only one of many methods on how to approach UI Design.

Understand how to use and implement Atomic Design

If you have more time try to do something bigger like design system thaat you can use in your future project, Goodluck!
